channel.title: Item handling
channel.description:
sup guys, some of you might know me by "hat trix". but i changed my password due to someone else using my account, and now i dont seem to remember my email :D. <- im a dumb-ass.
anyways, so i decided to start from pretty much scratch and create a new game. but i am running across a couple of problems in the game. i have the basics down, some things i didnt know how to do the "simple way", but i applied what i knew how to do, and everything is running smoothly. the thing i am having trouble with is item handling.
anyone ever played pokemon for the gameboy? i would like my "pack" to be just like that. as you collect items, it adds them in your pack, you can toss an item, and that item disappears causing the items below it to drop down a space, ect. anyone that can give me lead way to making my item handling similar to that, it would be nice.
[b]Important:[/b] also, i am looking for a second coder that wouldnt mind joining me in the production of my little 2d java game. someone that knows a little bit about java would be nice :)
the game is a pokemon based game, everyone has a little pokemon love deep deep inside there hearts. so far i have the first town 90% completed, 95% of the sprites were created by me (the other 5% to pokemon). i have not started working on pokemon battling yet, will do that later.

item.title: Item handling
item.dc:creator: @hat_trix hat trix
item.description:
@hat_trix wrote:

the way i have my items set up is like a list. so, in my paint method, i added this

for (int i1 = 0; i1 < itemid.length; i1++){
if (itemid[i1] == 0){
} else {
g.drawString("" + itemname[itemid[i1]], 115, ((i1 * 15) + 50));
g.drawString("X "+ammount[i1], 195, ((i1 * 15) + 50));
}

that makes it says something like sooo: this makes it draw the strings if the itemid is greater then 0. because 0’s item id is “nothing”, and it draws the ammount beside the item id. sooo lets say, i wanted to make you get an item if your coords are 4,10. i would say something like this…

if (playerX == 4 && playerY == 10){
additem(1,10);
}
if (playerX == 5 && playerY == 10){
additem(14,1);
}

now lets say i positioned my character on coords 4,10. then i placed him on coords 5,10. my inventory slot would look something like this now

potion    X 10
Bicycle   X 1

meaning i have 10 potions and 1 bicycle.
that make more since? if you would like the source, i will hand it out. as long as no one makes fun of my coding

here are some pics of it though, all sprites besides the walking models were drawn by me.

thats it so farr

Read full topic

item.title: Item handling
item.dc:creator: @Ollie Ollie
item.description:
@Ollie wrote:

I don’t understand your add item method, what is it supposed to do?

And slightly off topic, but I quite like Diablo’s inventory system.

Read full topic

item.title: Item handling
item.dc:creator: @hat_trix hat trix
item.description:
@hat_trix wrote:

well anyways. i got the inventory system. the problem i was having was when i had it set up like so…

public void additem(int id, int amm){
for (int i = 0; i <= itemid.length; i++){
itemid[i] = id;
ammount[i] = amm;
}
}

and i used… lets say,

additem(5,10)

it would come out like this

slot1: 1, 10
slot2: 1, 10
slot3: 1, 10
slot4: 1, 10
slot5: 1, 10

so i changed my code around to look like this

public static boolean addItem(int id,int amm){
if (emptyspace() > 0){
for (int i = 0; i < itemid.length; i++){
if (itemid[i] == id && ammount[i] < 999){
ammount[i] += amm;
return true;
}else {
if (itemid[i] <= 0){
itemid[i] = id;
ammount[i] = amm;
return true;
}
}
}
return false;
}return false;
}

and now it works. i think it has something to do with the returning true and false. because i had the code alot more simple then this in the begining. all i pretty much did was change it from void to boolean, and throw in some returns.

Read full topic
